Trump Comments on the Deaths of Alex Pretti and Renee Good Amid Minneapolis ICE Operations
item.description: Former President Donald Trump expressed his condolences over the deaths of Renee Nicole Good and Alex Pretti in Minneapolis during a Fox News interview. Good, a 37-year-old mother of three, was fatally shot by a masked ICE agent, Jonathan Ross, during a federal immigration enforcement operation. Pretti, a 37-year-old ICU nurse, was killed by immigration agents while filming officers at a protest. Trump stated that he felt particularly bad about Good’s death because her parents were strong supporters of him, describing them as 'tremendous Trump people.' He suggested that Good may have been 'radicalized' despite her family's political leanings. The Trump administration initially framed both victims as threats, with officials labeling Pretti as a would-be domestic terrorist and claiming Good attempted to harm agents with her vehicle. item.title: Guide to Locating Online Benefit Guides for Major Credit Card Issuers
item.description: When you receive a new credit card, it typically includes a physical 'Guide to Benefits' booklet that outlines purchase protections, travel insurance, and other safeguards like ID theft protection or concierge services in fine print. However, these booklets exclude many other perks such as rewards earning rates, annual free nights, companion certificates, or fee waivers. To access these guides digitally for easier reference—especially for purchase and travel protections—several major issuers provide them online. American Express offers separate documents for each benefit without requiring login at americanexpress.com/us/credit-cards/features-benefits/policies, where users select a benefit and then view the guide for their specific card. Capital One simplifies access via capitalone.com/credit-cards/benefits-guide, listing guides by card, with extra Mastercard details available through priceless.com. item.title: EU Chemical Industry Faces Significant Decline Due to High Energy Costs and Reduced Russian Gas Imports
item.description: The European Union's chemical industry has experienced a notable downturn largely linked to the economic fallout from sanctions on Russia following the 2022 invasion of Ukraine. Prior to the conflict, Russia supplied 45% of the EU's gas at prices 30-50% below US liquefied natural gas. Sanctions drastically cut these imports, forcing reliance on pricier alternatives and contributing to a reported 9% loss in chemical production capacity, according to industry sources like CEFIC. Specific 2024 production declines included Germany (25%), the Netherlands (20%), the UK (12%), France (10%), and Spain (8%). The sector's heavy dependence on natural gas not only for energy but also as a raw material for key compounds like ammonia and methanol amplified the impact. item.title: Severe winter storms and heavy snowfall cause at least ten deaths across Japan
item.description:
Japan has been severely affected by an intense winter weather episode marked by heavy snowfall, repeated cold waves, and strong winds, resulting in at least ten fatalities across several regions. According to Japan’s Fire and Disaster Management Agency (FDMA), the deadliest impacts were recorded in Niigata Prefecture, along the Sea of Japan coast, where six people lost their lives. Two of the victims died after being struck by snow falling from rooftops in the area of Nagaoka, while four others died during snow removal operations in different parts of the prefecture.
Additional deaths were reported in the prefectures of Hokkaido, Akita, Yamagata, and Shimane, with one fatality confirmed in each location. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) explained that a series of strong cold air masses caused widespread snowfall across Hokkaido, northern Tohoku, and the Hokuriku region. item.title: Elon Musk Shares AI-Generated Video Demonstrating Grok Updates on X
item.description: Elon Musk recently shared a brief AI-generated video on X featuring digital versions of Sydney Sweeney and Regé-Jean Page. The 10-second clip, set in a futuristic style with moody lighting, depicts the AI characters discussing updates to Grok, X’s AI tool. The video showcases improved audio quality and demonstrates the new capability for longer AI-generated clips. While some users praised Grok's technical advancements and its conversational features, others raised ethical concerns regarding the use of celebrity likenesses without consent. The clip also reignited broader debates about deepfake technology, including the potential for misuse and the challenge of distinguishing AI-generated content from reality. Musk framed the video as a product update, coinciding with a recent X platform outage, signaling that development on Grok continues despite technical setbacks. item.title: France Mandates Use of Domestic Visio Platform for Government Videoconferencing, Phasing Out US Tools like Zoom and Teams
item.description: The French government has decided to prohibit public officials from using American videoconferencing platforms such as Zoom, Microsoft Teams, and Google Meet. This policy shift is driven by a broader push toward digital sovereignty and reducing dependence on U.S.-based technology services amid growing concerns in Europe over data security and reliance on foreign providers. A spokesperson from the Interministerial Digital Authority (Dinum) confirmed to POLITICO that a formal notice is being prepared and will be published in the coming days. The notice will require state officials to switch to Visio, a home-grown videoconferencing solution developed by Dinum and hosted on infrastructure from the French company Outscale. This follows an announcement by Minister for State Reform David Amiel, who stated that France aims to fully adopt the domestic platform across government by 2027. Visio is already in use by around 40,000 staff members, including personnel from most ministries and entities

item.title: New England Dairy Farmer Raises Concerns Over Falling Milk Prices and Policy Impacts
item.description: A dairy farmer from New England has shared a heartfelt post on social media highlighting the severe financial challenges facing small dairy farms. Milk prices have fallen to around $14 per hundredweight, a level considered unsustainable for family-run operations. The farmer questions whether government policies, tariffs, bureaucratic processes, or large dairy cooperatives are partly to blame for the financial strain. They also express disappointment in political leaders, including former President Trump, whom they previously supported, for not addressing the hardships faced by dairy farmers. The post contrasts personal struggles with the broader political discourse, noting that some shared political content from pro-Trump pages clashes with the realities of farming life. Agricultural economists emphasize that milk prices are influenced by multiple factors, including production levels, feed costs, export demand, and cooperative pricing structures. item.title: Germany and France propose a core EU group to strengthen competitiveness and resilience
item.description: Germany is advocating for a 'two-speed' European Union to overcome decision-making delays within the 27-member bloc and enhance economic performance. German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil proposed forming a core group of six leading EU economies—including France, Poland, Spain, Italy, and the Netherlands—to coordinate key policies aimed at strengthening Europe's sovereignty, resilience, and competitiveness. The initiative comes as EU nations seek to reduce reliance on imported critical raw materials, especially from China, and address potential risks from global trade fragmentation. The German and French finance ministers emphasize advancing the capital markets union, reinforcing the euro as a stable international currency, improving defense cooperation, and securing strategic resources like rare earth minerals. item.title: South Carolina Measles Outbreak Reaches 789 Cases, Becoming Largest in US in Nearly 30 Years
item.description: The South Carolina Department of Public Health (DPH) reported that the state's ongoing measles outbreak has increased to 789 confirmed cases, marking an addition of 89 cases over the past four days. This figure exceeds the 760-762 cases from the 2025 West Texas outbreak, which originated in an under-vaccinated Mennonite community and resulted in two child deaths, making the current South Carolina outbreak the largest in the United States in nearly three decades. The epicenter remains Spartanburg County, where the virus initially spread in October 2025 through elementary and middle schools, many private Christian academies with largely unvaccinated student populations. Holiday gatherings and travel further accelerated community transmission. Most cases (695) involve unvaccinated individuals, with 14 partially vaccinated, 20 fully vaccinated, and 60 of unknown status. item.description: Following the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti, a 37-year-old intensive care nurse in Minneapolis by federal agents on January 24, 2026, Palantir employees expressed significant internal discontent regarding the company's ongoing contracts with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). In company-wide Slack channels, workers voiced ethical concerns, with one stating they viewed ICE as 'the bad guys' and felt ashamed of the association. They questioned the extent of Palantir's involvement in immigration enforcement, including whether the company could influence ICE practices or if its tools might contribute to improper targeting, such as detaining asylum seekers without criminal records. In response, Palantir's privacy and civil liberties team updated an internal wiki to outline its work, including a $30 million contract for the ImmigrationOS platform launched in April 2025. item.title: Tribute to El Loko Dope: Hip-Hop Activist from San Bernardo Murdered in Brutal Attack
item.description: Emilio Santiago Muíño shares a heartfelt personal remembrance of El Loko Dope, a Chilean hip-hop activist he met in 2007 in San Bernardo's URRAP collective during his time in Chile's activist Hip Hop network. Dope, once trapped in a severe addiction to pasta base—a drug devastating Santiago's peripheral neighborhoods—transformed his life through political hip-hop workshops, education popular, and community organizing. He became an exemplary figure of resilience, solidarity, and commitment to mutual aid, inspiring the author deeply and symbolizing hope against neoliberal destruction. Dope conducted powerful workshops, shared his story publicly to help youth escape addiction, and collaborated in music that linked personal struggle to collective resistance. Though contact faded over time due to distance, Dope remained a talisman of possibility for the author. item.title: Review: Staying at London Hilton on Park Lane with Suite Upgrade and Lounge Access Using Hilton Free Night Certificates
item.description: The review details a stay at the London Hilton on Park Lane over New Year's Eve using four Hilton free night certificates. The author and family, including their dog, chose this pet-friendly hotel with an executive lounge due to limited availability elsewhere. One room was upgraded to a spacious Deluxe Park Lane Suite featuring a large living room, dining area, balcony with views, king bedroom, walk-in closet, and a bathroom with shower and tub. The only minor issue was an opaque window between bedroom and bathroom causing light disturbance. The executive lounge, accessible via the wife's Diamond status for both rooms, offered a solid breakfast and an impressive evening canapes and drinks spread, extended until 10pm on New Year's Eve with free-flowing sparkling wine. The location on Park Lane is excellent, opposite Hyde Park and near Buckingham Palace, with good tube access. item.title: Germany Halts Further Delivery of Patriot Air Defense Systems to Ukraine
item.description: Germany has announced that it can no longer supply additional Patriot air defense systems to Ukraine, according to Defense Minister Boris Pistorius. Since the war began in 2022, Germany has been a major arms supplier to Ukraine, second only to the United States, spending nearly €20 billion on military aid up to October last year. The Defense Minister explained that German military production has reached its limits and that over a third of Germany's Patriot systems have already been delivered to Ukraine. Berlin must now focus on replacing the systems it has supplied and modernizing training and maintenance for its own forces. Data from the German Ministry of Economy shows a sharp drop in arms exports to Ukraine, from €8.15 billion the previous year to just €1.14 billion last year. item.title: Zimbabwe Accelerates Diplomatic Efforts to Join BRICS Bloc
item.description: Zimbabwe is actively pursuing full membership in the BRICS group, viewing it as a key strategy to accelerate economic development and overcome international isolation. Foreign Affairs Minister Amon Murwira stated in a recent interview that the government is making sustained diplomatic efforts to expedite integration into the bloc, under the direct oversight of President Emmerson Mnangagwa. Harare has initiated formal contacts with all BRICS member states, sending official correspondence and engaging in bilateral discussions with both African and international counterparts. The country is open to participating in BRICS activities according to current provisions while awaiting full admission. This proactive approach reflects a preference for swift collaboration rather than passively waiting for a formal invitation. item.description: The video features an audio recording of Ronald Reagan delivering a speech criticizing socialized medicine. He argues against government control of healthcare, emphasizing individual liberty and the potential for reduced quality and efficiency.

item.title: Vaonis Hyperia: A High-End Automated Telescope Designed for Museum-Level Astronomy
item.description:
The article explores the Vaonis Hyperia, a $99,000 smart telescope originally developed as a digital observatory for a major Paris science museum and now offered to institutions and private buyers seeking professional-grade astronomical equipment. Unlike conventional backyard telescopes, Hyperia is positioned as a bridge between consumer technology and institutional astronomy, combining large-scale physical presence with advanced digital automation.
Standing roughly six feet tall when deployed, the telescope features precision optics developed in collaboration with Canon, including a wide aperture, advanced lens coatings, and a large full-frame sensor. These components allow Hyperia to capture deep-sky objects with exceptional clarity, detail, and color depth, revealing stars, nebulae, and cosmic dust in a way that goes far beyond what the naked eye or entry-level telescopes can provide.

item.title: Report: Federal Agents Previously Broke Protester Alex Pretti's Rib and May Have Known His Identity Before Fatal Shooting
item.description: A report from The New Republic, citing CNN sources, reveals that Alex Pretti, a 37-year-old VA ICU nurse and Minneapolis protester, had his rib broken by ICE agents about a week before he was fatally shot by Border Patrol agents on January 24, 2026. The earlier incident occurred when Pretti stopped his car to observe and protest ICE agents chasing a family; he began whistling and yelling, leading five agents to tackle him, with one leaning on his back and causing the injury. Medication records reviewed by CNN were consistent with treatment for a broken rib. Sources indicated federal agents were aware of Pretti's name, potentially from a DHS surveillance database collecting information on Minneapolis protesters, amid a broader immigration enforcement surge. This raises questions about recognition during the fatal encounter. item.title: Kristi Noem Criticized by Wyoming Firearms Experts for Muzzle Sweep During ICE Photo Op
item.description: Department of Homeland Security Secretary and former South Dakota Governor Kristi Noem faced criticism after a publicity event in Arizona where she posed with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents while holding an M4 carbine rifle. Photos and video from the event showed the muzzle of her rifle tilting toward the head and face of an agent standing to her left, an action known as 'muzzle sweep.' This violates a fundamental firearms safety rule: always keep the muzzle pointed in a safe direction and never point a gun at anything you do not intend to destroy. Wyoming firearms experts, including retired peace officer and trainer Frank Groth and NRA-certified instructor Vince Vanata, emphasized the importance of muzzle awareness and treating every firearm as if it is loaded. They noted that even if the weapon was likely unloaded for the photo op, the breach in protocol was concerning, as an accidental discharge could cause injury from muzzle blast or other hazards. item.title: DHS Preliminary Report: Two Federal Agents Discharged Firearms During Fatal Shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, No Mention of Pretti Reaching for Weapon
item.description: A preliminary Department of Homeland Security (DHS) report, based on a review of body-worn camera footage and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) documentation, details the fatal shooting of 37-year-old U.S. citizen Alex Jeffrey Pretti in Minneapolis on January 24, 2026. The incident occurred amid federal immigration enforcement operations in the area. According to the report, CBP personnel ordered two female civilians to move out of a roadway during enforcement actions; when they refused, an officer pushed them, prompting one woman to run to Pretti for help. Agents then attempted to move Pretti and the woman, deploying oleoresin capsicum (OC) spray when they did not comply. Efforts to take Pretti into custody led to resistance and a physical struggle. During the altercation, a Border Patrol Agent (BPA) shouted 'He's got a gun!' multiple times. item.title: Slovak PM Fico expresses private concerns about Trump after Mar-a-Lago meeting
item.description: During an EU summit in Brussels on January 22, Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico privately expressed concern to fellow European leaders about U.S. President Donald Trump's state of mind following their meeting at Mar-a-Lago on January 17. Fico, usually a strong supporter of Trump, reportedly described the president as 'dangerous' and 'out of his mind' according to multiple European diplomats. The details of the conversation that triggered Fico's reaction were not disclosed. However, publicly, Fico praised the meeting on Facebook, highlighting discussions on Ukraine, U.S.-Slovakia relations, and the EU's challenges, and did not mention Greenland or other controversial topics raised by Trump earlier in January. Fico later denied POLITICO's report, calling it false, and reaffirmed his support for many of Trump's strategies. item.description: Bilt's recent rollout of its 2.0 credit cards, including the Blue, Obsidian, and Palladium variants, has encountered additional issues beyond previously reported rollout challenges. When launching the new cards, Bilt shared a screenshot detailing the Mastercard World Elite benefits for the Blue and Obsidian cards, and World Legend benefits for the Palladium card. For the no-annual-fee Blue card, the provided information listed benefits such as no foreign transaction fees, cellular wireless telephone protection, purchase assurance, MasterRental coverage, trip cancellation and interruption protection, and trip delay reimbursement. However, upon reviewing the official guide to benefits for the Blue card, trip cancellation and interruption protection as well as trip delay reimbursement are not included. item.title: Lavish Mar-a-Lago Event Occurs Hours After Fatal Shooting of Alex Pretti by Federal Agents
item.description: On January 24, 2026, Alex Pretti, a 37-year-old intensive care nurse and U.S. citizen, was fatally shot by U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents in Minneapolis, Minnesota. The incident occurred amid protests related to federal immigration enforcement operations in the city. Videos and witness accounts indicate Pretti was holding a phone while recording or observing the scene, not brandishing his licensed firearm, when agents approached, subdued him, and fired multiple shots. Federal officials initially described it as defensive action against a perceived threat, but investigations revealed protocol issues, leading to agents being placed on leave and an ongoing review. Stephen Miller acknowledged potential deviations from procedure, and President Trump promised an honest investigation. Pretti's family described him as kind and generous, devastated by the loss. item.title: EU proposes stricter foreign investment rules and joint ventures to boost industrial production
item.description: The European Commission is considering a major shift in its industrial strategy, inspired by China’s historical approach to economic growth. Under the proposed Industrial Accelerator Act (IAA), foreign companies investing in key strategic sectors of the EU would be required to form partnerships with European firms. These joint ventures would include mandatory sharing of know-how, a limit of 49% on foreign ownership, and a requirement to source half of manufacturing within the EU. The policy aims to raise industrial production from 14.3% of EU gross added value in 2020 to at least 20% by 2030. Critics argue that the move contradicts Europe’s long-standing commitment to open markets and could face legal and political challenges, including resistance from member states such as Sweden. item.title: Trump defends limits on carrying guns after fatal federal shooting of Alex Pretti
item.description:
The article reports on comments by U.S. President Donald Trump following the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Alex Pretti by federal agents. Before departing the White House for a trip to Iowa on Tuesday, Trump spoke briefly with reporters about the incident and was asked to respond to public concern. He described the situation as very sad, stressing that he felt compassion for Pretti’s family and referring broadly to his affection for “all of our people.”
When addressing the circumstances around the shooting, Trump emphasized that individuals “can’t have guns” and “can’t walk in with guns,” suggesting that carrying firearms into certain situations is unacceptable. His remarks prompted a reporter to challenge him by invoking the Second Amendment, which protects the right to keep and bear arms in the United States. Rather than directly engaging with the constitutional question, Trump repeated his point that people cannot walk in with guns and that such actions are not permitted.

item.title: US citizen five-year-old girl deported to Honduras with undocumented mother amid Trump administration immigration enforcement
item.description: A five-year-old U.S. citizen, Génesis Ester Gutiérrez Castellanos, was deported on January 11, 2026, to Honduras along with her mother, Karen Guadalupe Gutiérrez Castellanos, despite never having lived in the country. The mother, who entered the U.S. in 2018 fleeing poverty, received a deportation order in 2019 but stayed after giving birth to Génesis in 2020. Karen had applied for a U visa due to domestic violence from the child's father, but her application remained pending amid significant backlogs. The deportation followed a domestic disturbance call to Austin police, who discovered the outstanding ICE warrant and notified the agency. ICE detained the pair, holding them in a San Antonio hotel for nearly a week without immediate access to a lawyer, phone calls, or a judicial hearing, raising concerns about procedural violations and limited legal representation. item.title: Review of Autopilot Service for Automatic Flight Rebooking on Price Drops
item.description: Autopilot is a tool designed to monitor paid flight reservations and automatically rebook them when fares drop by $20 or more, securing airline credits for the difference while keeping the same flight, cabin, and seat. Users can add bookings manually, forward confirmation emails, or allow Gmail scanning (though the author prefers avoiding scanning). The service ensures rebookings stay within the same fare product, such as not switching from Economy to Basic Economy, though the specific fare class may change. It charges 25% of the savings under the 'Pay Per Win' plan with no upfront fee, or offers a Pro tier for $9.99/month that lowers the fee to 15% and adds monitoring for award reservations (notifying users of price drops for manual rebooking). Currently, it supports American, Delta, and United airlines, with plans to add JetBlue, Alaska, and eventually Southwest. item.title: ICE Fails to Report Eight Immigrant Deaths in Custody Despite Congressional Mandate
item.description: An investigation by Zeteo revealed that U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has failed to comply with federal law requiring disclosure of deaths occurring in its custody. Since February of the previous year, at least eight immigrants have died while detained by ICE, but the agency has not provided the necessary reports within the congressionally mandated 90-day period. This failure includes seven deaths since October across six states, as well as one case in Puerto Rico earlier in the year involving an alleged drug smuggler. The lapse in transparency violates statutes included in ICE’s funding legislation and raises questions about accountability in the nation’s detention system. The report comes amid an increase in the number of detainees under Donald Trump’s administration, with ICE operating its largest detention capacity in history. item.description: The video reports on protests in Minneapolis following the shooting of a man by federal agents. Demonstrators are demanding accountability and transparency regarding the incident. The video includes interviews with protesters and some details surrounding the event. It highlights the tense relationship between communities and federal law enforcement.

item.title: Philip Glass Withdraws Symphony No. 15 'Lincoln' Premiere from Kennedy Center Citing Value Conflict Under Current Leadership
item.description: Renowned American composer Philip Glass, aged 88 and widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in contemporary classical music, has withdrawn his latest work, Symphony No. 15 titled 'Lincoln', from its scheduled world premiere at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C. The premiere was set for June with the National Symphony Orchestra. Glass announced his decision on January 27, stating on social media that after careful consideration, he felt compelled to pull the piece because the symphony portrays Abraham Lincoln and embodies values that are now in direct conflict with those of the Kennedy Center under its current leadership. This leadership change stems from President Donald Trump's takeover of the institution, including his appointment as chairman, board restructuring with allies, and the renaming of the venue to incorporate his name as the Trump-Kennedy Center in late 2025. item.title: The Legal and Human Impact of Economic Sanctions and Blockades
item.description: The article examines economic sanctions and blockades as tools of modern geopolitical conflict, focusing on the long-standing U.S. embargo against Cuba. It traces the legal and historical background, citing the 1974 UN General Assembly Resolution 3314, which classifies the blockade of a state's ports in peacetime as an act of aggression. The 1986 International Court of Justice ruling against the U.S. in the Nicaragua case confirmed that interfering with peaceful maritime trade is illegal. The embargo against Cuba, in place since 1962, has caused severe humanitarian consequences, including widespread malnutrition and limited access to medical care. The individual, whose identity has not been released, was shot near milepost 15 of West Arivaca Road around 7:30 a.m. Emergency personnel from the Santa Rita Fire District and American Medical Response provided immediate care and transported the person via medical helicopter to a regional trauma center. Law enforcement authorities, led by the Pima County Sheriff's Department (PCSD) with assistance from the FBI, are actively investigating the circumstances of the shooting. item.description: The article discusses China's renewed and intensified engagement in Africa through the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) in 2025. Energy projects, including renewables like solar, wind, and hydro, as well as oil and gas, play a central role in addressing Africa's energy demands and strengthening Chinese market presence. When security intervened to escort her out, she allegedly resisted, pulling hair from one bouncer's scalp and striking another in the genitals, as captured on surveillance video. item.title: Colonial Legacies, Historical Amnesia, and Europe’s Moral Contradictions
item.description:
In this long-form opinion essay, Rafael Poch de Feliu argues that contemporary European complicity with Israeli policies toward Palestinians cannot be understood without confronting Europe’s own colonial past, particularly that of the British Empire. The author contends that Western governments, institutions, and media reproduce old imperial logics under new moral vocabularies, today framed around human rights, gender equality, and humanitarian discourse.
Poch emphasizes the ideological role of the entertainment industry, especially Hollywood and British cinema, in romanticizing colonial violence and transforming historical atrocities into heroic narratives. Films depicting imperial expansion in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East are presented as cultural tools that normalize domination and obscure mass suffering, such as famines, forced labor, and racial hierarchies.

item.description: The video shows an ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) agent attempting to enter the Ecuadorian consulate in Minneapolis. item.description: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has firmly stated that it will not permit the United States to launch any military attacks against Iran from its territory. item.description: In Minneapolis, recent ICE raids targeting migrant workers have created tension and instability among local businesses. item.description: The Indian tech industry, valued at around $280 billion and employing over 5 million people, is facing a growing crisis of mental health, burnout, and job insecurity. Nikhil Somwanshi, a 24-year-old machine-learning engineer, is one among many employees struggling under extreme workloads, with long hours and intense pressure exacerbated by the rise of AI-driven layoffs. Studies show that over 80% of tech workers experience burnout, many working over 70 hours per week, leading to physical health issues such as liver disease and organ failure. The pandemic and remote work have blurred the boundaries between personal and professional life, increasing stress levels. AI automation has begun threatening entry-level and mid-level positions, while global layoffs in the tech sector have amplified fears of job loss. item.description:

According to an official online bulletin, affected systems may fail to start and instead display a black screen accompanied by the stop code “UNMOUNTABLE_BOOT_VOLUME,” leaving users unable to complete the startup process without manual intervention.
The issue appears to primarily affect physical machines running Windows 11 versions 24H2 and 25H2. While Microsoft states that only a small number of reports have been received, the severity of the problem has raised concern, as impacted devices require recovery through the Windows Recovery Environment and the removal of the latest security update to restore functionality. item.description: Gregory Bovino, previously serving as Border Patrol's 'commander at large,' has been removed from his position and will return to his former post in El Centro, California, with retirement expected soon. His demotion follows the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Alex Pretti by agents under his command in Minneapolis. The incident has prompted the Trump administration to reconsider its aggressive immigration enforcement tactics, signaling a potential shift away from the nationwide mass-deportation campaign. item.title: Tourist Injured in Rare Snow Leopard Encounter Near Xinjiang Ski Area
item.description:
A female skier was injured in a rare wildlife encounter after being attacked by a snow leopard while skiing in Fuyun County, near China’s northern border with Mongolia. The incident occurred on a Friday evening when the tourist reportedly noticed the elusive animal in the snow and approached to within approximately ten feet in an attempt to take a photograph. Video footage circulating online shows the woman lying face-down in the snow following the attack, and later being escorted away with visible facial injuries and significant bleeding.
According to reports, a ski instructor intervened by waving his ski poles, successfully driving the snow leopard away and preventing further harm. Authorities stated that the woman’s ski helmet played a crucial role in protecting her from potentially life-threatening injuries. She was transported to a local hospital, where she was reported to be in stable condition.

item.title: China Advances Plans for Two Nuclear-Powered Probes to Explore the Heliosphere's Boundaries
item.description: China is developing an ambitious interstellar mission featuring two probes to investigate the heliosphere's structure and its interaction with the interstellar medium. Unlike previous missions such as the Voyagers, which relied on radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTGs), these probes will employ 1-kilowatt fission nuclear reactors using uranium-molybdenum alloy fuel, sodium coolant, and thermoelectric conversion with silicon-germanium alloys. This design ensures long-term power for over 30 years and allows safe launch in a shutdown state to prevent radioactive release in accidents. Each probe has a maximum mass of 8.2 tons, enabling launch aboard Long March 5 rockets, making this the second dual Long March 5 mission after Tianwen-3. item.description: Dog ownership today goes beyond choosing breeds based solely on appearance or temperament. Lifestyle, urban living, travel habits, and personal values increasingly influence breed selection. Active individuals may prefer energetic breeds like Border Collies, while apartment dwellers often choose smaller, adaptable dogs such as French Bulldogs. Travel habits also shape preferences, with portable breeds like Toy Poodles suiting frequent travelers, and resilient breeds like Siberian Huskies appealing to adventure seekers. item.description: On January 22, 2026, the United States officially withdrew from the World Health Organization (WHO), leaving the global health agency with hundreds of millions of dollars in unpaid dues. The US had previously informed WHO of its intent to exit a year earlier, but under a 1948 congressional resolution, member states are required to pay all financial obligations before leaving. item.description: Australia is a vast country, and choosing the right mode of transport can significantly impact your travel experience. This article compares four main options: car, plane, coach, and train, based on comfort, flexibility, speed, and cost. Driving a car offers maximum flexibility and allows travelers to explore remote areas at their own pace, though it can be slow and tiring. Air travel is the fastest option, especially for covering long distances like Sydney to Perth, but it can be costly and offers less freedom to explore remote regions. Coaches, such as Greyhound buses, are the most economical choice and can be convenient for overnight travel, but they are slower and less comfortable. item.description: A Reuters/Ipsos national poll conducted from Friday through Sunday found that only 39 percent of Americans approve of former President Donald Trump's handling of immigration, marking the lowest rating of his term on this issue. The drop comes in the wake of the fatal shooting of 37-year-old ICU nurse Alex Pretti by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis. Videos of the incident and subsequent public scrutiny have undermined claims from Trump administration officials, including Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and Deputy White House Chief of Staff Stephen Miller, who accused Pretti of being a 'domestic terrorist' and attempting to kill federal agents. item.description: Patty O'Keefe, a long-time Minneapolis resident, recounts being arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) while attempting to alert her neighbors about ICE operations in her community. item.description: Sal Buscema, renowned comic book artist and co-creator of several Marvel characters and titles, passed away at the age of 89, just before what would have been his 90th birthday. Born Silvio Buscema in Brooklyn, New York, in 1936, he began his career in the 1950s by inking his older brother John Buscema's work. He later joined Marvel Comics full-time in 1968 and quickly became known for his speed and reliability, earning the nickname 'Our Pal Sal'. He often inked his own work and co-created characters such as Lady Deathstrike, Jean DeWolff, Starhawk, and the Time Variance Authority. item.description:
Iran has seen a significant rise in the use of cryptocurrencies amid enduring international sanctions and an ongoing economic blockade. In 2025, cryptocurrency transactions in the country reached an estimated 7.8 billion USD—a record increase driven by growing public demand during times of crisis. Ordinary Iranians have been purchasing Bitcoin and other digital assets at a faster rate as inflation approaches 50% and the Iranian rial has lost nearly 90% of its value since 2022. For many, cryptocurrencies function as a means to protect their savings from rapid devaluation and economic instability.
However, this trend extends beyond the population. Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps reportedly uses cryptocurrencies as a tool to bypass Western financial restrictions, having accumulated around 3 billion USD in digital assets last year. item.description: A severe cold wave is currently affecting large parts of the United States, resulting in extreme temperatures, heavy snowfall, and icy conditions. At least 31 deaths have been reported, with incidents ranging from hypothermia to road accidents caused by unsafe travel conditions. Emergency services are actively assisting residents, particularly in densely populated areas where access to medical care and heating is limited. Infrastructure has been heavily impacted, with nearly 600,000 homes left without electricity due to damaged power lines from ice, snow, and falling trees. The outages are worsening the daily struggles of people facing subzero temperatures, creating significant health and safety risks. Technicians are working to restore electricity, but harsh weather conditions are slowing down repairs and posing additional hazards. item.title: Former French Senator Joël Guerriau Faces Trial for Allegedly Drugging MP Sandrine Josso
item.description: Joël Guerriau, a former centrist senator from Loire-Atlantique, has gone on trial in Paris for allegedly drugging fellow politician Sandrine Josso with MDMA in November 2023, in what prosecutors describe as an attempt to commit sexual assault. Josso, a 50-year-old member of parliament for the MoDem party, reported experiencing severe heart palpitations, nausea, and difficulty standing after consuming a champagne glass allegedly spiked by Guerriau at his apartment. She managed to escape and received assistance from a taxi driver and parliamentary colleagues, later filing a police complaint with the help of parliamentary leaders. Guerriau, who resigned from the Senate in October 2025, denies any intent to commit sexual assault, claiming the drink was served accidentally. The trial will examine evidence including Guerriau's internet search history prior to the incident. The death of Alex Pretti, who was shot and killed by a federal agent in Minneapolis, has prompted an outpouring of grief and reflection from family, friends and community members who describe him as compassionate, principled and deeply caring. A widely shared video shows Pretti, a registered nurse at the Minneapolis VA hospital, delivering a solemn final salute to a veteran he treated in the intensive care unit. In the recording, Pretti honors the veteran’s service with words of gratitude and respect, underscoring his commitment to caring for those who served the country.
Friends and neighbors recall Pretti as a quiet, warmhearted person who consistently showed kindness to others. He was known for his love of the outdoors and for the close bond he shared with his Catahoula Leopard dog, Joule, who recently died. item.description: According to a December 2025 letter by the ACLU of Texas, Human Rights Watch, and other human rights groups, detainees at Fort Bliss, Texas, have reported severe abuse and sexual torture by ICE officers. The facility, also known as Camp East Montana, currently houses over 2,700 people, making it the largest immigration detention center in the United States. Sworn declarations from detainees describe officers crushing testicles, slamming heads into walls, sexual assault, verbal humiliation, and denying access to medical care and lawyers. Another detainee, 'Isaac,' reported similar sexual abuse and threats of forced deportation to countries they had no ties to. item.description:
The article reports on a controversial court hearing in Jerusalem in which two Israeli soldiers accused of sexually assaulting a Palestinian detainee were greeted with applause from supporters inside the courtroom. The soldiers are among five members of an Israeli military unit charged with aggravated assault following an incident at the Sde Teiman detention camp in July 2024. A leaked video from the incident shows soldiers beating a Palestinian prisoner and later gang-raping him behind riot shields. The detainee was hospitalized with severe internal injuries and long-term trauma.
The court hearing did not focus on the alleged assault itself, but rather on a dispute over who should lead the investigation into the leak of the video footage. item.description:
Evangeline Lilly has opened up about the profound physical, emotional, and financial impact of recovering from a traumatic brain injury sustained after an accident last year. In a video shared on Instagram, the actor described fainting at a beach in May and falling face-first onto a boulder, an incident that resulted in a concussion and later a diagnosis of traumatic brain injury. Since then, she says her cognitive functioning has been noticeably affected, prompting her to seek extensive evaluations and highly specialized treatment.
Lilly explained that her recovery has required significant financial resources, as she pursued expert assessments and customized care tailored specifically to her condition. item.description: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is under intense scrutiny after reports surfaced of severe mistreatment of migrants at Fort Bliss, Texas. The facility, historically used as a WWII Japanese internment camp, is accused of widespread abuse, including physical beatings, sexual assault, and denial of basic necessities such as food, hygiene supplies, and medical care. A 19-page investigative report supported by the ACLU and Human Rights Watch documents over 80 violations of federal standards, including incidents where detainees were tortured to coerce deportation. Deaths in ICE custody have reached a 20-year high, further escalating concerns. Activists emphasize that detainees are often denied legal representation, restricting their ability to challenge abuse or detention. item.description:
A fatal shooting in Minneapolis has triggered rare and increasingly public criticism of President Donald Trump and federal law enforcement agencies from within the Republican Party. The incident involved the death of Alex Pretti, an ICU nurse and U.S. citizen who was active in recent protests. According to federal authorities, Pretti was described as a dangerous domestic threat. The killing has reignited debate over the conduct, training, and oversight of federal immigration enforcement. Several Republican officials have expressed alarm that the actions of federal agents may have violated constitutional protections and eroded public trust. item.title: Mount Athos: Historical Monastic Rules on Entry for Women, Animals, and Catalans
item.description: Mount Athos, a remote peninsula in northern Greece, has long been home to Orthodox monks living under strict ascetic traditions. For over a thousand years, it operated as an autonomous monastic republic with its own laws, recognized historically by Byzantine emperors, Ottoman sultans, Greek kings, and even the European Union. A rule called 'avaton', established in 1046, prohibited the entry of women to preserve the monks’ spiritual focus. Female animals were also banned to prevent distractions, although some, like cats and hens, were allowed for practical reasons. Interestingly, Catalans were historically banned due to a violent conflict in 1305 known as the 'Catalan Revenge'. Following the assassination of Roger de Flor and the massacre of Catalan mercenaries, the survivors retaliated brutally against the Byzantine Empire, including looting monasteries on Mount Athos. item.description:

Estimated at around four trillion euros and unfolding over the current and next decade, this transfer is described as one of the largest movements of private wealth in Spain’s recent history. item.title: The Blue Gemini Program: The US Military’s 1960s Space Capsule Project
item.description: Blue Gemini was a United States Air Force project in the 1960s that aimed to use a modified Gemini spacecraft for military purposes in low Earth orbit. Originally, the Gemini program was a NASA initiative, conceived as Mercury Mark II, to develop orbital docking and extravehicular activities before the Apollo missions. While NASA considered Gemini as a preparatory step toward Apollo, the military saw it as an opportunity to explore space operations for potential orbital stations. In 1962, the Blue Gemini program was launched to support MODS (Manned Orbital Development System), a planned military space station, which later evolved into the MOL (Manned Orbital Laboratory) featuring reconnaissance capabilities including the KH-10 DORIAN telescope. The program planned multiple missions, initially including both NASA and Air Force astronauts, with tasks such as docking with Agena targets, testing the Astronaut Maneuvering Unit, reconnaissance, and deployment of equipment. item.description: Recent reports indicate that funds recently added to United's TravelBank are showing an expiration date of one year from the date of deposit, instead of the standard five years. item.description: The Kaitai Struct Format Gallery serves as an extensive repository of file format specifications defined in the Kaitai Struct language. item.description:
The article discusses how the United States, under Donald Trump’s second administration, has adjusted its military strategy in response to an ongoing economic crisis. According to the piece, Washington is moving away from overextended global commitments and focusing instead on self-preservation and cost efficiency. The new U.S. national defense policy, presented by the Pentagon, signals a shift in how the country relates to its traditional allies, pressing them to take on greater responsibility for their own defense. item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Warns Against Political Polarization After Minnesota Shooting
item.description:
Former Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) spoke out following a controversial incident in Minnesota where a federal immigration agent fatally shot a man named Alex Pretti. Greene expressed her support for law enforcement and immigration control but emphasized her defense of the Second Amendment, stating that legally carrying a firearm does not equate to brandishing one. She also underscored the importance of First and Fourth Amendment rights, particularly the rights to protest peacefully and record public events.
In her comments posted on X, Greene urged supporters of former President Donald Trump to imagine how they might respond if similar events occurred under a Democratic administration. item.description: The article explores the ongoing loss of sonic diversity across the planet, describing how the rich variety of natural sounds—from birdsong and frog calls to whale songs and insect choruses—is diminishing due to multiple human-induced factors. item.description: The Dutch government is preparing to overhaul its wealth tax system, with plans to begin taxing capital gains annually by 2028. A parliamentary majority appears ready to support the proposal, although many lawmakers criticize its complexity and potential impact on investors. Under the new model, investors would pay tax on both realized and unrealized gains, meaning profits from stocks, bonds, or cryptocurrencies would be taxed even before assets are sold. This approach has sparked concern across the political spectrum, as many parties consider it unreasonable to tax theoretical, non-liquid earnings. item.title: Tree-ring study shows rising precipitation extremes in the western Mediterranean over the last five centuries
item.description: This research, published in *Climate of the Past* by Marcos Marín-Martín and colleagues, reconstructs 520 years of precipitation variability in eastern Spain using tree-ring data from *Pinus sylvestris* and *Pinus nigra*. The study area, located in the Iberian Range of Aragón, provides one of the longest and most detailed regional hydroclimatic records for the western Mediterranean. The authors developed a robust tree-ring chronology and correlated it with high-resolution precipitation datasets, achieving a strong relationship between annual ring growth and rainfall over a 320-day window from August to June. Their reconstruction shows substantial long-term variation in precipitation patterns since 1505 CE and, notably, a distinct intensification of both droughts and wet extremes since the late twentieth century. item.description: The article argues that capitalism in the United States has pushed millions toward extreme marginalization, introducing the sociological concept of the 'kill line'—a threshold where any life setback can lead to absolute ruin and street homelessness. item.title: Practical Strategies for Managing and Overcoming Depression
item.description: Depression often feels permanent and personal, convincing individuals that something is inherently wrong with them and that change is impossible. However, it is a temporary state rather than a character flaw, and recovery involves gradual, realistic steps rather than sudden fixes. Key hurdles include low energy and motivation; the article emphasizes starting with small actions—like getting out of bed, opening a window, or completing one task—because waiting for motivation rarely works, and even minor progress can weaken depression's hold. Cognitively, depression distorts neutral events into personal failures, so gently questioning these thoughts—distinguishing facts from feelings—and considering positive overthinking can help. Isolation worsens the condition, making connection vital, even through low-effort interactions like sharing a laugh or sending a message, as human contact counters the brain's insistence on loneliness. item.title: The Ongoing Scientific Challenges in Understanding Consciousness
item.description: The article explores why consciousness remains one of science's most elusive mysteries, tracing its potential evolutionary origins to the Cambrian explosion when complex brains enabled unified sensory experiences, emotions, and self-awareness. It highlights the shift from philosophical dualism to materialism and the field's revival in the 1990s through pioneers like Francis Crick and Christof Koch, who used tools like fMRI to seek neural correlates of consciousness via experiments on visual illusions and binocular rivalry. Despite decades of progress, including maps of brain networks active during awareness and tools to detect consciousness in impaired patients, no consensus exists on its definition or mechanisms. Key theories include global neuronal workspace (GNWT), higher-order theories, predictive processing, and integrated information theory (IIT), which posits consciousness arises from complex, integrated information and even suggests panpsychist implications. item.title: How the Ukraine War Has Strengthened Russian National Identity and Public Support
item.description: The article explores why the Russian population has not risen up against the war in Ukraine nearly four years after its start. Initially met with shock and confusion in February 2022, public attitudes have shifted significantly due to prolonged conflict, state propaganda, and external pressures. Many Russians now view the war as defensive against perceived Western hostility, fostering widespread anti-Western sentiment and national consolidation. Pride in Russia's resilience amid sanctions, combined with economic growth despite heavy restrictions, has boosted optimism and trust in the nation's viability. The war has spurred technological innovation, reinforced the social contract of state-provided services, low taxes, and public investment, which Russians see as superior to Western models. Cultural shifts include a turn inward after Western 'cancellations,' leading to a boom in domestic arts, tourism, and patriotic figures replacing emigrated celebrities. item.title: Yellowstone National Park Endures a -37°F Winter in Striking Slow-Motion Footage
item.description:
This article presents a visually rich portrait of Yellowstone National Park during one of its most extreme winter periods, when temperatures plunged to an unforgiving -37°F (-38°C). Despite the brutal cold, life across the park continues with remarkable resilience, a theme captured through the lens of filmmaker Drew Simms. His video offers a quiet yet powerful meditation on endurance, showcasing how wildlife and geothermal features coexist within a frozen landscape.
Viewers are taken deep into Yellowstone’s winter environment, where frost-covered bison move steadily across snow-laden plains, their thick coats acting as natural insulation. Coyotes appear alert and adaptable, navigating the harsh terrain in search of food, while mountain goats remain watchful along icy ridges. The film also highlights Yellowstone’s iconic geothermal features, with steaming hot springs and geysers creating dramatic contrasts against the surrounding snow and ice. Niseko in Hokkaido offers dreamlike scenes of snow-laden birch forests that blur sky and ground in quiet, immersive tranquility. Rather than attempting conventional defense, the strategy shifts to unconventional, insurgency-style tactics inspired by Afghan resistance against Soviet and later U.S.-led forces, including ambushes, sabotage, drone operations, hit-and-run attacks, and improvised explosives. The focus would be on small, mobile units and reservists inflicting ongoing casualties to make occupation costly and difficult. item.title: Braided vs. Silicone Cables: Durability and Performance Comparison
item.description: Choosing the right cable material – whether it’s braided or silicone – significantly impacts its durability and performance. Braided cables, often constructed from woven nylon or polyester, are known for their longevity and resistance to fraying and bending. The textured weave provides a firm grip and prevents tangling, making them ideal for travel and demanding work environments. Magnetic charging solutions, such as those offered by Statik, often leverage this design to enhance exterior strength without adding excessive weight. In contrast, silicone cables offer exceptional flexibility and heat resistance, remaining soft even in cold temperatures and minimizing the risk of kinking. Their smooth, rubber-like surface, while comfortable and easy to handle, can be prone to attracting dust and lint. item.title: The Importance of Raw Coffee Bean Quality in Flavor and Sustainability
item.description: The quality of raw, unroasted coffee beans plays a fundamental role in the taste, aroma, and overall enjoyment of the final brewed cup, far beyond the brewing method itself. High-quality beans are characterized by uniform size, consistent color, appropriate moisture levels, and minimal defects, all influenced by factors such as growing altitude, soil composition, microclimate, and origin region. For example, beans from higher altitudes often develop more complex and vibrant flavor profiles with bright acidity and fruity or floral notes, while Arabica varieties generally offer smoother, more nuanced tastes compared to the stronger, more bitter Robusta. The article details the coffee journey from farm to cup, stressing careful selective harvesting of ripe cherries and processing techniques—washed for cleaner acidity, natural for fruitier body, or honey for balanced sweetness—that shape distinct characteristics. item.title: La contención de EE. UU. con Irán y el peso de la energía y las finanzas en el equilibrio geopolítico
item.description:
El texto es un editorial que interpreta la decisión de Estados Unidos de cancelar en el último momento un ataque contra Irán en junio de 2019 como un acto de cálculo geoestratégico más que de proporcionalidad moral. Según el autor, la clave no estuvo en evitar víctimas, sino en prevenir una escalada que pudiera desestabilizar el sistema energético y financiero global, muy ligado al petróleo y al dólar. UU. y Arabia Saudí en los años setenta, ha sido un pilar de la hegemonía estadounidense, pero muestra fragilidades. item.title: Gianni Fresu analiza la vigencia del pensamiento de Gramsci ante la crisis de hegemonía global
item.description:
La entrevista publicada por teleSUR recoge una extensa reflexión del filósofo italiano Gianni Fresu sobre la actualidad del pensamiento de Antonio Gramsci en un contexto de crisis política, social y cultural a escala global. Fresu sostiene que vivimos un momento de “éxito hegemónico absoluto” de las clases dominantes, en el que amplios sectores populares acaban apoyando proyectos políticos que refuerzan su propia subordinación. Este fenómeno, explica, se debe a la combinación de neoliberalismo radical, autoritarismo y manipulación digital, lo que denomina una “subversión reaccionaria del mercado”.
El autor subraya que Gramsci no debe leerse como una figura del pasado, sino como un instrumento analítico útil para comprender y transformar la realidad contemporánea, especialmente en el Sur Global. item.title: La falta de deflactación del IRPF y su impacto real en la clase media
item.description:
La noticia analiza un fenómeno fiscal poco visible pero con efectos muy relevantes sobre los ingresos de los trabajadores: la denominada progresividad fría del IRPF. Este efecto se produce cuando los salarios aumentan para compensar la inflación, pero los tramos y deducciones del impuesto sobre la renta no se actualizan conforme al encarecimiento del coste de la vida. En términos reales, el contribuyente no es más rico, pero acaba pagando más impuestos.
El texto explica que deflactar el IRPF significa ajustar los límites de los tramos y las deducciones a la inflación para evitar subidas fiscales encubiertas. Cuando esto no ocurre, pequeñas subidas salariales pueden situar al contribuyente en un tramo impositivo superior, incrementando el porcentaje de impuestos que paga por una renta que mantiene el mismo poder adquisitivo.

item.title: EFE reabrirá las estaciones de Rosario y Requínoa en marzo de 2026 tras su modernización
item.description:
La Empresa de los Ferrocarriles del Estado (EFE) de Chile ha confirmado la reactivación de las paradas ferroviarias de Rosario y Requínoa, situadas en la Región de O’Higgins, durante la primera quincena de marzo de 2026. El anuncio fue realizado por el presidente de EFE, Eric Martin, y por el gobernador regional, Pablo Silva, tras la recepción oficial de las obras el pasado 26 de enero de 2026. Con la entrega formal de los recintos por parte del Gobierno Regional, la empresa estatal ha iniciado los trabajos preparatorios necesarios para retomar el transporte de pasajeros en estas estaciones.
La reapertura tiene un especial significado en el caso de Requínoa, cuya estación permanecía cerrada desde mayo de 2017. El proyecto de rehabilitación comenzó en septiembre de 2024 y ha supuesto una inversión superior a los 1.370 millones de pesos chilenos, financiados íntegramente por el Gobierno Regional de O’Higgins y su Consejo Regional. item.title: La exigencia de datos de redes sociales a viajeros podría reducir el turismo hacia Estados Unidos
item.description:
Una propuesta normativa en Estados Unidos que obligaría a algunos viajeros extranjeros a facilitar información sobre sus cuentas de redes sociales está generando preocupación en el sector turístico internacional. Según el Consejo Mundial de Viajes y Turismo (WTTC), esta medida podría disuadir a una parte relevante de visitantes potenciales y traducirse en pérdidas económicas millonarias para el país. A partir de una encuesta a casi 5.000 viajeros frecuentes de distintos países, el WTTC estima que alrededor de un tercio sería menos propenso a viajar a EE.UU. si, para usar el programa de exención de visado (ESTA), tuviera que aportar datos de sus redes sociales. En el peor de los escenarios planteados, el país podría perder hasta 4,7 millones de llegadas internacionales y unos 15.700 millones de dólares en gasto turístico, además de más de 150.000 empleos vinculados al sector.

item.title: Análisis de la Caza: Marina Lobo analiza el cese de Héctor de Miguel y la impunidad nazi
item.description: El vídeo es un análisis de la periodista Marina Lobo sobre el reciente cese de Héctor de Miguel, director de El Español, y su posible relación con el caso 'La Caza'. Lobo explora las implicaciones políticas y la supuesta impunidad que rodea el caso y sus figuras relacionadas.

item.title: El tranvía de Santa Cruz de Tenerife modifica su servicio del 31 de enero al 2 de febrero por trabajos de mantenimiento
item.description:
Metrotenerife llevará a cabo una serie de modificaciones temporales en el servicio del tranvía de Santa Cruz de Tenerife durante el fin de semana comprendido entre el sábado 31 de enero y el lunes 2 de febrero de 2026. Estas alteraciones responden a la ejecución de obras de mantenimiento en la plataforma ferroviaria, necesarias para garantizar la seguridad y el buen funcionamiento de la infraestructura.
Durante esos días, la Línea 1 del tranvía funcionará únicamente de forma parcial, limitando su recorrido al tramo comprendido entre las paradas de Intercambiador y Chimisay. El resto del trayecto hasta la estación de La Trinidad quedará cubierto mediante un servicio alternativo gratuito de guaguas, organizado en coordinación con la empresa de transporte insular TITSA, con el objetivo de minimizar las molestias a los usuarios habituales.
Por su parte, la Línea 2 suspenderá completamente su actividad durante todo el periodo de las obras. Esta interrupción afectará también al servicio no

item.title: La Comisión Europea recuerda que la regularización de inmigrantes es competencia de los Estados miembros
item.description:
La Comisión Europea ha rechazado el intento del Partido Popular y Vox de elevar a nivel comunitario el debate sobre la regularización masiva de inmigrantes anunciada por el Gobierno español. El comisario europeo de Interior, Magnus Brunner, dejó claro en Bruselas que la decisión sobre el estatus legal de las personas migrantes en situación irregular corresponde a cada Estado miembro y no a las instituciones europeas. En una comparecencia ante la prensa, Brunner afirmó que, aunque la Unión Europea trabaja para reducir la migración irregular y endurecer su política común en esta materia, las regularizaciones de personas que ya residen en un país son una cuestión interna de cada Estado.
El comisario subrayó que la regularización impulsada por España no contradice necesariamente los objetivos del Pacto Europeo de Migración y Asilo, ya que se trata de personas que ya se encuentran en territorio nacional. Además, señaló que estas decisiones pueden estar vinculadas a necesidades concretas de

item.title: El FMI destaca el crecimiento de España impulsado tanto por la mano de obra como por la productividad
item.description: Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas, economista jefe del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), señala que España se encuentra entre los puntos positivos de la eurozona gracias a un crecimiento sostenido que no solo depende del aumento de la mano de obra, sino también de mejoras en la productividad. En su entrevista con EL PAÍS, Gourinchas subraya que la economía española se ha beneficiado del turismo y de la llegada de trabajadores extranjeros, pero que en los últimos años también se ha producido un incremento de la eficiencia productiva, acercándose gradualmente a otras economías europeas. Sin embargo, advierte que la contribución del crecimiento ligada al aumento de la fuerza laboral se irá moderando y que se prevé una ligera ralentización del PIB del 2,3% en 2026 al 1,9% en 2027, con un crecimiento potencial situado en el 1,7%, superior al promedio de la zona euro. Además, Gourinchas analiza la situación global, destacando los efectos de la guerra comercial iniciada por Estados Unidos y la res

item.title: Metrotenerife pone fin a la huelga del tranvía tras un acuerdo con los sindicatos y mejora de las condiciones laborales
item.description:
Metrotenerife y las organizaciones sindicales CCOO, UGT y USO han ratificado un acuerdo definitivo que pone fin a la huelga del tranvía en Santa Cruz de Tenerife, un conflicto laboral que se prolongaba desde febrero de 2024. El pacto fue respaldado mayoritariamente por la plantilla en una asamblea celebrada esta semana, lo que permite recuperar la estabilidad del servicio a partir del viernes 30 de enero.
El acuerdo formalizado entre la empresa y el comité de huelga recoge una serie de medidas orientadas a mejorar las condiciones de trabajo y la seguridad de los empleados. Entre los compromisos más relevantes se encuentra la retirada progresiva de la arena de sílice del sistema de frenado de los tranvías, un material cuya exposición ha generado preocupación por sus posibles efectos sobre la salud. Este proceso de sustitución comenzó ya en junio de 2025 y continuará de forma escalonada hasta completarse.

item.title: El Auditorio Adán Martín en Tenerife, en deterioro, pendiente de una reforma de 24 millones
item.description: El Auditorio Adán Martín, obra del arquitecto Santiago Calatrava en Tenerife, presenta un avanzado estado de deterioro, con daños visibles en su fachada y zonas con cinta americana, mientras el Cabildo de Tenerife (CC-PP) no ha ofrecido novedades sustanciales sobre la reforma necesaria desde hace casi un año. La presidenta del Cabildo, Rosa Dávila, había culpado en 2024 al PSOE y Cs de la falta de acción en mandatos anteriores y anunció que se retomaría el proyecto con la colaboración del arquitecto, que se niega a entregar los planos a la oposición por considerarlos documentos técnicos no definitivos. La reforma se estima en 24 millones de euros, aunque cálculos previos oscilan entre 2,6 millones y 24 millones según informes de 2017 y 2022. La polémica sobre quién debe asumir los costes persiste, dado que Calatrava responsabiliza a las empresas que ejecutaron la obra original, y el acuerdo con estas compañías no ha resuelto la situación. item.title: Sevillano de 67 años con 30 años cotizados recibe pensión no contributiva de 564 euros tras denegación de la contributiva por falta de carencia específica
item.description: En España, la jubilación contributiva requiere no solo un mínimo general de cotización, sino también la llamada 'carencia específica': al menos dos años cotizados en los últimos quince anteriores a la jubilación. Un sevillano de 67 años, con 30 años y cuatro meses cotizados a lo largo de su vida laboral, se encontró con que la Seguridad Social le denegó la pensión contributiva porque no cumplía este requisito, ya que llevaba muchos años en paro sin cotizar al final de su carrera. Tras la denegación, sin explicaciones claras según relata, quedó sin ingresos y llegó a dormir en la calle durante siete meses en condiciones muy duras. Finalmente, recurrió al Defensor del Pueblo y obtuvo una pensión no contributiva de 564 euros mensuales, que apenas le alcanza para pagar una habitación alquilada por 170 euros, dejándole prácticamente nada para subsistir. item.title: Confirmada la identidad de los restos del guerrillero antifranquista Manuel Girón tras 75 años
item.description:
Setenta y cinco años después de su asesinato, los restos del guerrillero antifranquista Manuel Girón Bazán han sido identificados en Ponferrada gracias a un exhaustivo trabajo científico e institucional. El alcalde de la ciudad, Marco Morala, anunció que el análisis genético y antropológico ha permitido confirmar que uno de los cuerpos exhumados en el antiguo cementerio del Carmen corresponde a uno de los maquis más conocidos de la posguerra española.
Manuel Girón, figura clave de la resistencia antifranquista en el noroeste peninsular, fue dado por muerto hasta en cuatro ocasiones por la Guardia Civil antes de caer definitivamente en agosto de 1951, cuando fue abatido por la espalda por un agente infiltrado en los puentes de Malpaso. Tras su muerte, su cuerpo fue exhibido durante varios días como escarmiento público, reflejo del clima de represión y violencia de la época.

item.title: La estación 11 del Metro de Bogotá alcanza el 70,72 % de avance y se integra con TransMilenio
item.description:
La construcción de la estación 11 de la Primera Línea del Metro de Bogotá progresa favorablemente y ha alcanzado un avance del 70,72 % al cierre de diciembre de 2025, según el cronograma establecido. Esta estación elevada se ubica en la Avenida Caracas, entre las calles Primera y Primera B, en el límite entre las localidades de Mártires y Santa Fe, y contará con tres niveles, dos plataformas para trenes en ambos sentidos y un diseño bioclimático que favorece la ventilación natural.
La infraestructura beneficiará a barrios como San Bernardo, Eduardo Santos y Sevilla, ofreciendo servicios comerciales como restaurantes, droguerías, cajeros automáticos y amplias zonas de aparcamiento para bicicletas. Destaca su función como nodo intermodal clave: conecta directamente con la estación Hospital de TransMilenio, evitando desplazamientos largos, y se integra con rutas del Sistema Integrado de Transporte Público (SITP). item.title: Tres guardias civiles de Madrid se sientan en el banquillo por chantaje y uso indebido de datos oficiales
item.description: Tres agentes de la Unidad de Seguridad Ciudadana de la Comandancia de Madrid (USECIC) están siendo juzgados por presuntamente utilizar su posición para cometer delitos de chantaje, robo, agresiones y acceso indebido a información confidencial. La Fiscalía de Madrid sostiene que los acusados, mientras estaban en servicio activo en la Cañada Real Galiana, aprovecharon los sistemas informáticos de la Guardia Civil para localizar personas con causas judiciales pendientes y exigirles dinero a cambio de no denunciarlas. Uno de los casos más graves involucra a un vecino identificado como Javier J., a quien se le exigían pagos semanales de 500 euros, acumulando un total de 8.000 euros mediante esta extorsión. Además, los agentes habrían transmitido información reservada a terceros, consultando expedientes judiciales de manera no justificada y manteniendo viva la amenaza de detención para sostener el chantaje. item.title: El recorrido de Podemos: del auge popular a la disolución interna
item.description: El artículo narra la trayectoria del partido español Podemos desde sus orígenes en las protestas anti-austeridad del movimiento 15-M en 2011 hasta su declive y desintegración política en los años posteriores. La autora, Lilith Verstrynge, describe su experiencia personal dentro del partido, desde sus primeros pasos como miembro de un círculo en París hasta ocupar cargos relevantes en el Parlamento Europeo y en el Ministerio de Derechos Sociales en España. Podemos surgió como un movimiento capaz de movilizar a jóvenes y ciudadanos desencantados con el sistema bipartidista, logrando en 2014 cinco escaños en el Parlamento Europeo y en 2019 entrar en la primera coalición de gobierno de España junto al PSOE. Sin embargo, la falta de estructura interna, la dependencia de líderes mediáticos como Pablo Iglesias y la gestión de crisis de comunicación y escándalos mediáticos debilitaron el proyecto. La autora destaca cómo la presión política, los ataques falsos y la transformación de la base soc

item.title: La complicidad europea con el genocidio en Gaza a través del legado colonial británico
item.description: El artículo de Rafael Poch analiza la complicidad de gobiernos, instituciones y medios europeos con las acciones israelíes en Gaza, atribuyéndola al legado histórico del colonialismo europeo, especialmente el británico. Este imperio se presenta aún como modelo civilizador pese a su historia de violencia, racismo y explotación. Hollywood y la cultura popular han romantizado crímenes coloniales en películas como 'Lawrence de Arabia' o 'Victoria y Abdul', ocultando realidades como el narcotráfico en China o las hambrunas inducidas. Se destaca el 'Gulag británico' con deportaciones masivas a Australia y otras colonias, la Gran Hambruna irlandesa de 1845-1852 —con exportación de alimentos pese a la muerte de hasta dos millones de personas y condiciones mortales en los barcos 'ataúd'— y las hambrunas en India que causaron hasta 100 millones de muertes entre 1880 y 1920 por políticas coloniales. item.title: Cargos y familiares del Ayuntamiento de Alicante acceden a viviendas públicas y el alcalde abre una investigación interna
item.description:
La adjudicación de viviendas públicas en Alicante ha generado una fuerte polémica tras conocerse que entre los beneficiarios figuran personas con vínculos directos con el Ayuntamiento. Al menos una concejala en activo, un arquitecto municipal del área de Urbanismo y los dos hijos de una alta directiva municipal han adquirido viviendas en la promoción pública Les Naus, construida sobre suelo municipal en la zona de la Condomina. Se trata de la primera promoción de este tipo en la ciudad en los últimos veinte años, en un contexto marcado por la escasez de vivienda y el elevado precio del mercado libre.
La promoción consta de 134 viviendas de tres y cuatro dormitorios, con servicios como piscina, gimnasio y zonas deportivas, levantadas sobre una parcela municipal enajenada en 2022 y adjudicada a una cooperativa privada. item.title: He presentado mi segunda demanda judicial contra Daniel Esteve (Desokupa)
item.description: El vídeo muestra a una persona que ha presentado su segunda demanda judicial contra Daniel Esteve, conocido como 'Desokupa', aparentemente relacionada con asuntos legales o reclamaciones que la persona ha tenido con Esteve. El contenido probablemente explica los motivos de la demanda y el curso de la acción legal.

item.title: Trayectoria y legado de Robert Silverberg en la ciencia ficción
item.description:
El artículo repasa en profundidad la vida y carrera del escritor estadounidense Robert Silverberg, una de las figuras más prolíficas y premiadas de la ciencia ficción. Nacido en 1935 en Brooklyn, desde niño mostró una fuerte inclinación por la lectura y la escritura, especialmente tras descubrir la ciencia ficción a través de cómics y clásicos como Julio Verne y H. G. Wells. Muy joven empezó a publicar relatos en revistas del género y pronto destacó por una productividad fuera de lo común.
Durante los años 50 se convirtió en un autor extremadamente fecundo, capaz de escribir cientos de relatos y numerosas novelas, a menudo bajo seudónimos y adaptándose a las demandas del mercado. Esa etapa le dio éxito económico, pero también desgaste creativo. A finales de la década abandonó temporalmente la ciencia ficción, dedicándose a libros divulgativos y otros trabajos editoriales.

item.title: El tranvía de Santa Cruz de Tenerife modifica su servicio por obras de mantenimiento este fin de semana
item.description:
Metrotenerife ha anunciado modificaciones temporales en el servicio del tranvía de Santa Cruz de Tenerife con motivo de una serie de trabajos de mantenimiento programados en la infraestructura ferroviaria. Estas alteraciones afectarán a las líneas 1 y 2 desde el sábado 31 de enero hasta el lunes 2 de febrero de 2026, con el restablecimiento del servicio habitual previsto para el martes 3 de febrero, una vez concluidas las labores técnicas.
Durante este periodo, la Línea 1 funcionará de manera parcial, limitando su recorrido al tramo comprendido entre las paradas de Intercambiador y Chimisay. El resto del trayecto hasta La Trinidad será cubierto por un servicio alternativo de guaguas gratuito, coordinado con la empresa pública TITSA, con el objetivo de garantizar la movilidad de los usuarios afectados. Por su parte, la Línea 2 quedará completamente suspendida durante los tres días que duren los trabajos, sin posibilidad de circulación de convoyes.
